text: Hi! I have been running into a few different issues with the Markdown stdlib and wanted to propose a refactor of how the tests are structured, so existing behavior and edge cases are clearly demonstrated. What is the best way to solicit feedback on a possible approach? Or is it preferred that one just generate a PR and then ask for a review? <https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/blob/master/stdlib/Markdown/test/runtests.jl|https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/blob/master/stdlib/Markdown/test/runtests.jl>

elements.text: Hi! I have been running into a few different issues with the Markdown stdlib and wanted to propose a refactor of how the tests are structured, so existing behavior and edge cases are clearly demonstrated. What is the best way to solicit feedback on a possible approach? Or is it preferred that one just generate a PR and then ask for a review?

text: Yes, a pull request is probably the the best way to get concrete feedback

elements.text: Yes, a pull request is probably the the best way to get concrete feedback

text: Awesome. Are you interested in this topic? Or do you know of others who might want to be tagged in the PR once I have something written up?

elements.text: Awesome. Are you interested in this topic? Or do you know of others who might want to be tagged in the PR once I have something written up?

text: If you want to float your ideas before you do a bunch of work in reorganizing it, you might want to consider an issue first describing what you want to do.

elements.text: If you want to float your ideas before you do a bunch of work in reorganizing it, you might want to consider an issue first describing what you want to do.

text: Great, will do that. Do you have suggestions on how to find ppl who would be interested in giving feedback?

elements.text: Great, will do that. Do you have suggestions on how to find ppl who would be interested in giving feedback?

text: Probably the same people that want to get rid of it, see <https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/issues/37337>
